paragraphs.name: 54e0
paragraphs.text: 4.Promote yourself wisely. Many women are bad at collecting evidence of our success, let alone sharing it with others. We brush off compliments and downplay achievements. Then, when it’s time to ask for that promotion or raise, we can’t even communicate why we deserve it. Does your boss know what you’re capable of? Or even what you’ve already done? Are you making your accomplishments visible, or are you sitting quietly and hoping someone will notice your hard work? Make sure your boss and others know what you’ve contributed.

paragraphs.name: e344
paragraphs.text: 2. Stop worrying about coming off as aggressive. In fact, don’t worry so much about what others think of you in general. Instead, focus on whether you are being aggressive enough by your own standards, and whether you are supporting other women in doing the same. It’s liberating, and will empower you to focus on what matters instead.

1.Make being aggressive a positive thing. When we aggressively work on something, whether it’s fighting for the rights of our children, or our employees, or anything else that matters to us in life, we’re simply working hard, with passion, and putting forth our best effort. That is something we should never shy away from.

paragraphs.name: 8b0d
paragraphs.text: 5.Assume that you’re qualified. Many women wait to be asked (or worse yet, told) to jump in and take on a new challenge. Sometimes, we care so much about others’ opinions that we wait to be validated by someone else’s opinion of our readiness. Start with a default assumption that you’re capable, and go for it. Why not? Men do it all the time!

paragraphs.name: a1ba
paragraphs.text: Like many other women who have worked aggressively to get where they are, I don’t care about being the richest woman in the graveyard. But I do care about enriching the lives of others while I’m still here. And while I’ve never been strictly motivated by money or awards, the ability to achieve financial independence and pave the road for other women are parts of a legacy I actually do want to leave behind.

5.Assume that you’re qualified. Many women wait to be asked (or worse yet, told) to jump in and take on a new challenge. Sometimes, we care so much about others’ opinions that we wait to be validated by someone else’s opinion of our readiness. Start with a default assumption that you’re capable, and go for it. Why not? Men do it all the time!
paragraphs.name: 8b0d

876b666f6db.title: This. I’m amazed at how much time I wasted waiting to be given permission.

paragraphs.name: 7e7b
paragraphs.text: This. I’m amazed at how much time I wasted waiting to be given permission. I’m embarrassed now at the people I wanted permission from — they were not superior to me, and I didn’t need to ask. And I try to tell all the women that I meet that the dudes fake it till they make it as a way of life, because I really had no idea, and I wish someone had told me earlier.

2518dbfbb4d2.title: Great advice from a successful woman on taking life by the horns!

paragraphs.name: d10b
paragraphs.text: Great advice from a successful woman on taking life by the horns! I’m just not sure I understand the sexist overtone. I’ve been told many times that “all work and no play makes for a dull boy.” I think plenty of men would benefit from your wisdom if we’re only humble enough to receive it.

virtuals.subtitle: It makes me feel like using the word as an adverb makes it sound better somehow.

paragraphs.name: c669
paragraphs.text: It is very easy, in fact too easy, to accept someone else’s definition of what it means to be a “good girl” AND therefore worry about whether we’re conforming to that definition. The easy way out includes definitions supplied to us by our parents, teachers, male superiors, religious leaders and society at large. By accepting someone else’s definition…

17bd78fe7c3d.title: I normally don’t comment on articles about feminism.

content.subtitle: I just wanted to comment that I agree women should not be discouraged from seeking growth in any field, with full ambition. But many, like…

paragraphs.name: b3ad
paragraphs.text: I normally don’t comment on articles about feminism. As a man I think I lack credibility on the subject and as the spouse of a stay at home mom I think I might not even be welcomed in the space. But since we share a relatively rare event, being held hostage at gunpoint, I am risking it. That experience also changed my life, starting me on a spiritual…

paragraphs.name: 2af7
paragraphs.text: Such a great read, Nataly! Thanks for all the tips! In my career and life so far, I’ve heard this many, many times about myself but have learned that the drive to achieve and push forward is not something I should be ashamed of or scared of showing just because I’m a woman, a short woman in fact — this seems to surprise so many people.

b46224a43b25.title: So true, and often “side projects” are what capture the attention of others and can easily evolve…

paragraphs.name: 4d77
paragraphs.text: So true, and often “side projects” are what capture the attention of others and can easily evolve into a full-time gig! Totally agree with the feedback of not waiting for someone to “annoint” you and just doing it.

paragraphs.name: 17ad
paragraphs.text: I really appreciate the time you took to write about your experience. It’s incredibly important for women to share their stories. It’s been both fascinating and frustrating to watch how thin that line can be between being seen as too aggressive or putting yourself in a position to be taken advantage of. My wake up moment was my husband getting…

paragraphs.text: I’m so glad you found it helpful, Francesca! Glad I could provide a “nudge.” We all need them now and then!

virtuals.subtitle: I really allowed myself to be torn up over these comments for a long time—even though I had the support of my colleagues and other clients…

paragraphs.name: d981
paragraphs.text: Love. This. Nataly. I was once told by a client of mine (in marketing) that I was “aggressive and hostile,” in response to putting forth so much energy and effort to come up with a solution in an emergency situation. However, my own colleagues (and even her colleagues), said that I was calm, cool, collective, and direct with how I handled everything…

252031321990.title: This part struck me the most.

paragraphs.name: 5ed4
paragraphs.text: This part struck me the most. Women and minorities have so many invisible barriers to overcome. What a refreshing statement!

paragraphs.name: e53c
paragraphs.text: This is outstanding! Thank you. I appreciate your 5 point breakdown and the fact that you don’t sugar coat the environment. Many kudos to you for success and for promoting the success of other women!

paragraphs.name: 4edc
paragraphs.text: Remarkable story and incredible advice! Thanks for sharing and I couldn’t agree more. Aggressively, assertively, insanely, passionately, let’s continue to speak up and support each other. It is the only way we will every see change for our daughters and their daughters.

beb0ffb69906.title: Just what I needed to hear!

paragraphs.name: 6a2e
paragraphs.text: Just what I needed to hear! I’d add one more to your list, “don’t wait for someone to ‘let’ you take charge.” I’m a developer and was in a job at a large firm where the one time I was asked to lead I was told “you just want things your way” (yes? as an experienced lead, don’t you?). Additionally, I got the promotions but was never “asked to the…

paragraphs.name: 1f73
paragraphs.text: Awesome piece! I’m inspired by your journey and clarity. Thanks for the practical suggestions too – very helpful.
